cluster_classes.class_description: Biological structures and materials involved in the caterpillar-to-butterfly metamorphosis, including dissolving internal organs, the intermediate liquefied substance, and the newly forming tissues and appendages.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form.

members.entity_description: Internal biological structures of the caterpillar that dissolve during metamorphosis.
Liquid-like biological material formed when caterpillar organs dissolve inside the chrysalis during metamorphosis.
Fresh biological tissues that develop from liquefied organs during metamorphosis.
Sensory appendages that develop as new structures during butterfly metamorphosis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical structures involved in the butterfly life cycle and metamorphosis, including the larval body and the protective pupal casing.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: caterpillar's body undergoes significant changes during metamorphosis; protective pupa casing in the butterfly life cycle

members.entity_description: The hardened, protective casing enclosing the pupa stage of a butterfly, within which metamorphosis occurs and from which the adult butterfly emerges.
The overall physical structure of the caterpillar, including its tissues and organs, that changes significantly during metamorphosis.

args.new_description: Biological and anatomical structures and materials involved in butterfly metamorphosis, including larval body structures, dissolved organs and liquefied material, the chrysalis, and newly forming tissues and appendages such as wings and antennae.
args.justification: Both classes describe anatomical/biological components specifically involved in butterfly metamorphosis (caterpillar body, chrysalis, dissolving organs, liquefied material, new tissues, antennae) with no clear, stable conceptual boundary between them, so a single unified class for metamorphosis anatomical structures is more coherent.

The merged class clearly belongs to a broader domain covering anatomical structures involved in insect (specifically butterfly) metamorphosis, so assigning a stable Class_Group improves schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes describe anatomical/biological components specifically involved in butterfly metamorphosis (caterpillar body, chrysalis, dissolving organs, liquefied material, new tissues, antennae) with no clear, stable conceptual boundary between them, so a single unified class for metamorphosis anatomical structures is more coherent.

The merged class clearly belongs to a broader domain covering anatomical structures involved in insect (specifically butterfly) metamorphosis, so assigning a stable Class_Group improves schema connectivity.
